chapter.title: Getting started
chapter.subtitle: Trying &PROD; clustering with your own data
chapter.para: This chapter will show you how to use &PROD; in a number of typical scenarios such as trying clustering on your own documents or integrating &PROD; with your software.

section.title: Requirements
section.para: All &PROD; applications require Java Runtime Environment version 1.8 or later. The &DCW; is distributed for Windows, Linux and MacOSX.
The &CSA; package requires the .NET Framework version 3.5 or later; it does not require a Java Runtime Environment.

section.title: Trying &PROD; clustering
section.para: This section shows how to apply &PROD; clustering on documents from various sources.

section.title: Clustering results from common search engines
section.para: To try &PROD; clustering on results from search engines (such as Microsoft Bing), you can either:

listitem.para: Use the on-line version of &WA;
Use the &DCW; which can fetch and cluster documents from the same search engines as the &WA;

section.title: Clustering documents from XML files
section.para: To try &PROD; clustering on documents or search results stored in a single XML file you can use the &DCW;.

listitem.para: In the Search view of &DCW;, choose XML source.
Set path to your XML file in the XML Resource field.

(Optional) If your file is not in &C2; format, create an XSLT style sheet that transforms your data into &C2; format, see for an example. Provide a path to your style sheet in the XSLT Stylesheet field in the Medium section.
If you know the query that generated the documents in your XML file, you can provide it in the Query field, which may improve the clustering results. Press the Process button to see the results.

section.title: Clustering documents from XML feeds
section.para: To try &PROD; clustering on documents or search results fetched from a remote XML feed, you can use the &DCW;. As an example, we will cluster a news feed from BBC:

listitem.para: In the Search view of &DCW;, choose XML source.
Set URL to your XML feed in the XML Resource field. Optionally, the URL can contain two special place holders that will be replaced with the Query and Results number you set in the search view.
In our example, we will use the BBC News RSS feed.

Create an XSLT style sheet that will transform the XML feed into &C2; format. For the news feed we can use the stylesheet shown in . To add more colour to our results, the XSLT transform extracts thumbnail URLs from the feed and passes them to &PROD; in a special attribute. Attributes that are a sequence of values can be embedded as shown in .
Provide a path to the transformation style sheet in the XSLT Stylesheet field in the Medium section.
Press the Process button to see the results.

figure.title: News feed XML to &PROD; format transformation
figure.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <xsl:stylesheet version="1.0" xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss">
<xsl:output indent="yes" omit-xml-declaration="no" media-type="application/xml" encoding="UTF-8" />
<xsl:template match="/"> <searchresult> <xsl:apply-templates select="/rss/channel/item" /> </searchresult> </xsl:template>
<xsl:template match="item"> <document> <title><xsl:value-of select="title" /></title> <snippet> <xsl:value-of select="description" /> </snippet> <url><xsl:value-of select="link" /></url> <xsl:if test="media:thumbnail"> <field key="thumbnail-url"> <value type="java.lang.String" value="{media:thumbnail/@url}"/> </field> </xsl:if> </document> </xsl:template> </xsl:stylesheet>

figure.title: Document attribute that contains a list of values.

section.title: Clustering documents from a Lucene index
section.para: To try &PROD; clustering on documents from a local Lucene index, you can use &DCW;:

listitem.para: In the Search view of &DCW;, choose Lucene source.
Choose the path to your Lucene index in the Index directory field.
In the Medium section, choose fields from your Lucene index in at least one of Document title field and Document content field combo boxes.
Type a query and press the Process button to see the results.

section.title: Clustering documents from a Solr index
section.para: To try &PROD; clustering on documents from an instance of Apache Solr, you can use &DCW;:

listitem.para: In the Search view of &DCW;, choose Solr source.
In the Advanced section, provide the URL at which your Solr instance is available in the Service URL field.
In the Medium section, provide fields that should be used as document title, content and URL (optional) in the Title field name, Summary field name and URL field name field, respectively.
Type a query and press the Process button to see the results.

tip.para: &PROD; clustering can also be performed directly within Solr by means of Solr's &PROD; Clustering Component.

section.title: Saving documents or clusters for further processing
section.para: To save doocuments and/or clusters produced by &PROD; for further processing:

listitem.para: Use &DCW; to perform clustering on documents from the source of your choice.
Use the File > Save as... dialog to save the documents and/or clusters into a file in the &C2; XML format.

tip.para: Saving documents into XML can be particularly useful when there is a need to capture the output of some remote or non-public document source to a local file, which can be then passed on to someone else for further inspection. Documents saved into XML can be opened for clustering within &DCW; using the XML document source.

section.title: Compiling a Java program using &PROD; API
section.para: The easiest way to integrate &PROD; with your Java programs is to use the &JA; package:

listitem.para: Download &JA; and unpack it to some local directory.
Make sure that carrot2-core.jar and all JARs from the lib/ directory are available in the classpath of your program.

Look in the examples/ directory for some sample code. Good places to start are ClusteringDocumentList and ClusteringDataFromDocumentSources. For a complete description of &JA;, please see Javadoc documentation in the javadoc/ directory.
You can use the build.xml Ant script to compile and run code from the examples/ directory.

tip.para: For easier experimenting with &JA;, you may want to set up a &PROD; project in Eclipse IDE.

section.title: Setting up a &PROD; project in Eclipse IDE
section.para: &JA; examples can be easily set up in Eclipse IDE. The description below assumes you are using Eclipse IDE version 3.4 or newer.

listitem.para: Download &JA; and unpack it to some local directory.
In your Eclipse IDE choose File > New > Java Project.

In the New Java Project dialog (), type name for the new project, e.g. &PRODID;-examples. Then choose the Create project from existing source option, provide the directory to which you unpacked the &JA; archive and click Finish.

When Eclipse compiles the example classes, you can open one of them, e.g. ClusteringDocumentList and choose Run > Run As > Java Application. The output of the example program should be visible in the Console view.

section.title: Setting up &PROD; source code in Eclipse IDE

important.para: To set up &PROD; source code, you will need Eclipse IDE version 3.5 or later with the Plug-in Development Environment (PDE). The required plugins are avaiilable e.g. in Eclipse for Plug-in Developers and Eclipse Classic distributions available at .

listitem.para: Check out &PROD; source code using git:
In the Package Explorer view in Eclipse IDE, choose Import... (see ), select General > Existing Projects into Workspace and click Next.
In the Import projects dialog provide your local &PROD; checkout directory in the Select root directory field. Uncheck the org.carrot2.antlib project (see ) and click Finish.
All &PROD; source code should compile without errors. If it does not:
Make sure your Eclipse's Java compiler compliance level is set to 1.5 or higher (Preferences > Java > Compiler).
Make sure your Eclipse's workspace encoding is set to UTF-8 (Preferences > General > Workspace > Text file encoding).

section.title: Compiling a C# program using &PROD; API
section.para: The easiest way to integrate &PROD; with your C# / .NET programs is to use the &CSA; package:

listitem.para: Make sure you have .NET framework version 3.5 or later installed in your environment.
Download &CSA; and unpack it to some local directory.
Compile example code based on the provided msbuild project file:
Try running the executable files generated in the examples\ folder.

tip.para: The provided msbuild project is not directly compatible with Visual Studio To create a &PROD; project in Visual Studio, import the example source code and all the referenced DLLs to an existing or newly created project.

section.title: Calling &PROD; clustering from non-Java software
section.para: To integrate &PROD; with your non-Java system, you can use the &DCS;, which exposes &PROD; clustering as a REST/XML service. Please see for installation instructions and the examples/ directory in the distribution archive for example code in PHP, C# and Ruby.
